bibl.title: John Bowler and Edward McCrinkle v. James H. Bennett. Petition for Writ
bibl.note: Our transcription is based on a digital image of the microfilmed original.

org.orgName: District Court of the Third Judicial District of Washington

body.p: FILE No. 6068
In the District Court of the Third Judicial District of Washington Territory, Holding Terms at Seattle W.T.
in the matter of the application of john bowler et. al for writ of habeas corpus
john bowler and edward mccrinkle petitioners vs. the united states marshal et. al.
to the honorable r.a. jones judge of the above entitled court
your petitioners john bowler and edward mc. crinkle respectfully petition your honor to wit: -
i. that they are now illegaly, and unjustly restrained of their liberty by the united states marshal for the territory of washington at the county jail of king in the city of seattle

ii. that the pretense of the said illegal restraint is a certain committment issued from the united stated commissioner, c.d. emery purporting to charge the petitioners herein with perjury, the said committing reciting that there was probable cause to believe the said petitioners guilty of the said charge

iii. that the illegality of the said restraint consists in this to wit:- 1st. the said c.d. emery had no jurisdiction of the said alleged offense as the time if committed at all was in an extra judicial proceeding and not before a competent tribunal ministerial or or judicial 2. there was no cause whatsoever, and no probabale cause to believe the said petitioners herein guilty of the said judgment. 3d. the said commissioner kney he acted unlawfully and immediately after ward to wit after the rendit on of the said judgment admitted the said error, and that he knew the same, 4th. the said commissioner was in a condition both physically and mentally which absolutely precluded the possibility of the said commissioner form properly, justly or righteously passing upon the rights of the petitioner herein. 5th. the said commissioner had no jusrisdiction whatsoever 6th.

wherefore the said petitioner pray that your honor will grant unto them a writ of habeas corpus bringing your petitioners before your honor at such time and place as to your honor may seem meet that your honor will inquire 1st. as to the jurisdiction of the said united states commissioner in the premises. 2nd. as to whether there was and is probable cause to suspect your petitioners of the offense charged. 3rd. that your honor will examine into all the facts of the said case and do justice in the premises to your petitioners. and your petitioners will ever pray etc.
lewis and gilman + attys. for petitioner
territory of washington county of king s.s.

personally appeared before me to notary public in and for the territory of washington john bowler, who upon oath says that he is one of the petitioners herein, that he has heard read the foregoing petition and knows the contents of the same and that the same are true as he believes. sworn to and subscribed before me this 28th. ady of june a.d. 1888.
notary public for washington territory.
In re petition of John Bowler et al for Habeas Corpus and discharge
Petition
FILED Jun 28 1888
W.E. Ledgerwood, Clerk. Cannon, Deputy.
Lewis + Gilman Attorneys at law, Seattle, Wash. Ter.
